messages.text: <https://forums.swift.org/t/formalizing-swift-generics-as-a-term-rewriting-system/45175/5|https://forums.swift.org/t/formalizing-swift-generics-as-a-term-rewriting-system/45175/5>

attachments.title: Formalizing Swift generics as a term rewriting system
attachments.text: I believe this is a counterexample: ab -> x ba -> y xa -> z Consider the term aba. If we apply the first rule, we get xa. If we apply the second rule, we get ay. Now xa can be reduced to z by the third rule, but ay cannot be reduced further. This means that (ay, z) is a critical pair. If we introduce the rewrite rule ay -> z, then aba will reduce to z irrespective of the whether we apply the first rule or second rule initially. Edit: I realized what you might be getting at is that if our rew...
attachments.fallback: Swift Forums: Formalizing Swift generics as a term rewriting system

elements.text: https://forums.swift.org/t/formalizing-swift-generics-as-a-term-rewriting-system/45175/5

messages.text: I recently found out about a really cool generalization of prime sieves <https://www.rieselprime.de/ziki/Sieving>. Basically it lets you sieve for primes within arithmetic sequences (`ax+b`). I'm sure this is well known in some circles, but it is new to me and can be really useful for some number theory problems.

elements.text: I recently found out about a really cool generalization of prime sieves
. Basically it lets you sieve for primes within arithmetic sequences (
ax+b
). I'm sure this is well known in some circles, but it is new to me and can be really useful for some number theory problems.

messages.text:
:linux:
<https://spectrum.ieee.org/automaton/aerospace/robotic-exploration/nasa-designed-perseverance-helicopter-rover-fly-autonomously-mars>

"This the first time we‚Äôll be flying Linux on Mars. We‚Äôre actually running on a Linux operating system. The software framework that we‚Äôre using is one that we developed at JPL for cubesats and instruments, and we <https://github.com/nasa/fprime|open-sourced> it a few years ago. So, you can get the software framework that‚Äôs flying on the Mars helicopter, and use it on your own project."

elements.text: "This the first time we‚Äôll be flying Linux on Mars. We‚Äôre actually running on a Linux operating system. The software framework that we‚Äôre using is one that we developed at JPL for cubesats and instruments, and we
open-sourced
it a few years ago. So, you can get the software framework that‚Äôs flying on the Mars helicopter, and use it on your own project."

messages.text: PyTorch is getting JAX like code transforms: <https://twitter.com/cHHillee/status/1367621541693857794>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/cHHillee|@cHHillee>: Since your transformation takes in Python code and outputs Python source code, they're
1. Automatically composable with each other
2. Automatically composable with anything else (like Torchscript).
3. Able to be dumped out as Python code. 

Here's an example (2/4) <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvrDp5TVkAAJt7z.png>
attachments.text:
Since your transformation takes in Python code and outputs Python source code, they're
1. Automatically composable with each other
2. Automatically composable with anything else (like Torchscript).
3. Able to be dumped out as Python code. 

Here's an example (2/4) <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvrDp5TVkAAJt7z.png>

messages.text:
So time dilation. I have a physicist friend and we were engaging in some banter:

Me: How was your week
Them: Long
Me: But wasn't it seven days
Them: Time is relative
Me: But not to you


That's correct right?  Meaning the perception of a week (neuroscience aside) will always be the same because you're fixing the interval and observer

elements.text:
So time dilation. I have a physicist friend and we were engaging in some banter:

Me: How was your week
Them: Long
Me: But wasn't it seven days
Them: Time is relative
Me: But not to you


That's correct right?  Meaning the perception of a week (neuroscience aside) will always be the same because you're fixing the interval and observer

messages.text:
‚ÄùDolt is Git for Data!

Dolt is a SQL database that you can fork, clone, branch, merge, push and pull just like a git repository. Connect to Dolt just like any MySQL database to run queries or update the data using SQL commands. Use the command line interface to import CSV files, commit your changes, push them to a remote, or merge your teammate's changes.

All the commands you know for Git work exactly the same for Dolt. Git versions files, Dolt versions tables. It's like Git and MySQL had a baby!‚Äù

<https://github.com/dolthub/dolt|https://github.com/dolthub/dolt>

elements.text: ‚ÄùDolt is Git for Data!

Dolt is a SQL database that you can fork, clone, branch, merge, push and pull just like a git repository. Connect to Dolt just like any MySQL database to run queries or update the data using SQL commands. Use the command line interface to import CSV files, commit your changes, push them to a remote, or merge your teammate's changes.

All the commands you know for Git work exactly the same for Dolt. Git versions files, Dolt versions tables. It's like Git and MySQL had a baby!‚Äù
https://github.com/dolthub/dolt

messages.text: has anyone ever had this happen to them:  attempting to replace a cpu cooler fan, I released the mounting brackets but the thermal paste was so sticky that when I pulled the fan out it didn't detach from the cpu, it pulled the CPU out of the socket with the fan--pulling all the pins out of the locked CPU socket.  Amazingly all the pins look fine

messages.text: As someone having this channel as my only entry point to the broad world of programming related blog posts, I'm always puzzled. I have no idea of their relevance or whether they have audience and not a single clue to how the people sharing them discovered them in the first place. Also I am amazed by how plentiful they are.

messages.text:
I wrote a python script for the first time in a year or so yesterday, and I realized that I don't much like the way of performing a function using the dot-accessor after the variable. Like
```foo = "water melon"
foo.split()[0]```
It just feels a little weird. Totes not a deal breaker or anything.

messages.text:
I wanted to know how a particular thing that involved wrapping a C-library was done.
So I was like _‚ÄúI will take a glance at the python library that wraps that C library. See how they do it‚Äù_
But no.
The ‚Äúpython‚Äù wrapper, is itself implemented about 50% in C.
Because of course it is.

messages.text: no, `=` is not a normal operator in Julia, it is special syntax.  You'd need a macro to do that (which I'm sure would kind of defeat the purpose)

is not a normal operator in Julia, it is special syntax.  You'd need a macro to do that (which I'm sure would kind of defeat the purpose)

messages.text: I wonder if it would be completely insane to allow all binary operators to also be defined as macros?  seems like it would have a ton of really nice uses, but on the other hand it could get horribly confusing if people don't use this power responsibly

So LLVM Fortran has a REPL now:
<https://twitter.com/lfortranorg/status/1367507839535640578>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/lfortranorg|@lfortranorg>: Thanks to <https://twitter.com/DominicPoerio|@DominicPoerio>, LFortran now has a multi-line REPL in a terminal (works on all platforms), and it uses the tokens to determine if the line is complete, so you only have to press Enter and it will automatically start a new line such as in the if statement below: <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Evpci-XUUAA3hbE.jpg>

messages.text:
Today in far-left ideas:
If the subtyping algorithm of Swift can be recast as a term re-writing problem (vis. <https://forums.swift.org/t/formalizing-swift-generics-as-a-term-rewriting-system/45175>), Can the Julia subtyping algorithm be recast as term rewriting with Symbolics.jl? <@U687RKK0E>

attachments.title: Formalizing Swift generics as a term rewriting system
attachments.text: Formalizing Swift generics as a term rewriting system Previously I wrote about how the full generality of the Swift generic system is undecidable. The basic idea is that "finitely-presented monoids" can be written as a Swift protocol where the "word problem" on the monoid reduces to proving an equivalence between two types. Since the word problem is known to be undecidable, this shows that Swift generics (as currently defined) are undecidable. In that post, we started with a finitely-presented ...
attachments.fallback: Swift Forums: Formalizing Swift generics as a term rewriting system

elements.text:
Today in far-left ideas:
If the subtyping algorithm of Swift can be recast as a term re-writing problem (vis.
), Can the Julia subtyping algorithm be recast as term rewriting with Symbolics.jl?
